comments.commentBody:
What active support did the Muslim who killed four of our marines in Kentucky get? What active support did the Boston marathon bombers get? Accessing an online bomb making publication originating in Kuwait?
If the San Bernardino killers got active support from persons in Pakistan or Saudi Arabia, those Governments should be held accountable. But, as was the case with the Saudi born killers on September 11, I doubt those Governments will be.

Here is a link to a page on the FBI's website that lists the various definitions of 'terrorism' under U.S. law. None of those definitions includes a requirement of a support network; in fact, none of them even mentions the term or any synonym for the term. Try again.

https://www.fbi.gov/about-us/investigate/terrorism/terrorism-definition
Like Obama held Assad responsible for crossing that line in the desert sand, Mike?  "Wolf!  Wolf!"

The difference between mass shootings and terrorism as it exists today is a support network. The mass shooters are truly lone wolfs with mental issues and act alone without support. The Islamic terrorists have an extensive support network that encourages, supports, and actively provides information on how to create IEDs. That this has to be pointed out to some I find curious. The active support that Islamic terrorists enjoy is the obvious difference.

The significance of this difference is that it is possible to track the support network and make attempts to disrupt it.

The fact that plot 1 of the anchored inflation expectation for the Euro area has slope is close to the US is coincidental

Here are some values from ECo/WKP (2015) 49 for the Euro Area

Greece - 0.84
Italy - 0.51
Slovak Republic + 0.4 (not a misprint, its positive !)

BTW, expected inflation is difficult to measure. Survey invariably return the expected inflation including energy and food, which are not in the core inflation.

Rusticelli1, David Turner1, Maria Chiara Cavaller make the point in effect, been replaced by the inflation targets that the Central Banks set and that are printed in Newspapers and discussed on Radio and TV.

This article is truly a stretch. It's obvious this author's prior relationship with the Shoops has pointed his direction. Purdue did not have any problem with what the Shoops did off the field. His coaching results simply did not justify retention. I am frankly embarassed that The Times published this lopsided article as anything but an opinion piece. I thought this was a good quality news organization; but once I read this, it made me realize how clouded and biased it's writers could be.
See the data for Europe in my new post. No special pleading here.

Anyone who has watched the Purdue offense for the last three years knows exactly why Shoop was fired. I personally challenge Joe Nocera to sit through each and every one of those games and tell me this firing was not absolutely justified solely on the basis of Shoop's performance.
Is Shoop a recruiter? When last I noticed most coaches are no better than their players.
The lack of intelligent thought put into this piece is appalling, illusory correlation abound.

Joe Nocera should be forced to watch replays of this season's Purdue games. He might then have some appreciation for why Shoop's firing is totally justified.

It's interesting that he cites as substantiation of Shoop's prowess that Purdue scored 38, 36 and 55 points in three games. The 38 were against Indiana State ('nuf said). The 36 were against Indiana, who also gave up 55 to Rutgers, whose coach was just fired.

And the 55 against Nebraska were the result of the Cornhuskers starting a walk-on quarterback who threw 4 interceptions that led to TDs created by the defense. Sports Illustrated described the Nebraska loss under the following headline: "Nebraska Hits New Low with Embarrassing Loss at Purdue".

And by the way, Shoop didn't "recruit and nurture all those young players". The only group he spent much time with was the QBs.

Morgan Burke has made many mistakes. Firing Shoop wasn't one of them.

Morgan does not run Purdue Athletics like a business. He runs it like a political statement. I have interviewed him regarding his record of proactively hiring African American coaches, and wanted to ask him if the NCAA needed a "Rooney" rule. He said he would not answer any questions related to professional sports because college athletics are NOT a stepping stone to the pros.

Morgan puts the education over the performance of the Athletes, because he is of the Opinion that performance in the classroom will carry them farther than their performance on the field. That's where his 85/25 concept comes from. The goal is to have 85% of the athletes get their degree and the teams to finish in the Top 25 in their sport.

His philosophy doesn't always result in Wins, and he'd be a lot better off taking money from the University, but to say that the man is anti-student rights is a joke. As some have already pointed out, the offense has been terrible and Shoop has never found a consistent game plan. Markell Jones rushed for 157 yards against Michigan State and received fewer than 10 touches the next week.

Shoop didn't perform, plain and simple.

On another note, why should the athletic department that doesn't take money from the academic side of the University give money to an Academic programs pursuit?

The bottom line is that John Shoop is not a good offensive football coach.  He has held positions with 8 different college and pro organizations over the past 24 years.  His stay at Purdue was 3 years.  This seems to be the going rate for how long it takes for people to realize that John Shoop is not a successful coach.  The facts are simple, Purdue Football is as bad as it has been in over 20 years.  Purdue ranked 12th, 13th and 11th in the Big Ten in total offense in his 3 years as coordinator.  He had his chance and was not able to succeed.  I am certainly no fan of Morgan Burke or Mitch Daniels, but the only mistake they made when firing John Shoop was not sending Darrell Hazell with him.

http://www.washingtonpost.com/sf/sports/wp/2015/11/23/running-up-the-bills/ I'm sorry this article from the Washington Post clearly states Purdue Athletics operates at a deficit of Millions of dollars. All scholarships are paid for by Donations from the John Purdue Club, whose membership is dwindling, because of a terrible offensive performance.
Who were those "Elite 11 Quarterbacks?"
Sorry, I accidentally posted this under the wrong thread. Appleby, Etling and Blough were Elite 11 QBs.

He had 3 - yes 3 "Elite 11 Quarterbacks" on his roster.
Enough said.

You lost me at this: "... or how according to the Washington Post, Purdue athletics does operate at a deficit of millions and is heavily dependent on student fees."
Perhaps you can provide a reference.

According to this 2013 article:
http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/college/2013/05/07/ncaa-finances-su...
there are only seven athletic departments that are entirely self-supporting--LSU, Texas, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Penn State, Ohio State, and Purdue. The last four are in the Big Ten, where all teams share equally the enormous income from the Big 10 TV Network.

Until recently, the Purdue athletic department put $1M annually into the university's general fund.

Don't disparage OLS based on your preconceived notions. I can say first hand that the baseline expectations were not challenging, but that the program and professors intentionally allow for greater flexibility and support when students wanted to push themselves. Blough could easily be that type of student, and I hope he uses those resources to get an excellent preparation for a career.
If you are unhappy with Daniels as President of Purdue, fine. But to try and link that to an offensive coordinator in this case is borderline delusional.
Etling, Appleby and Blough, I believe we're all Elite 11 QBs.

I really love the Shoop's and hope they continue to be strong advocates for student and player's rights. But I you think for one second I'm going to watch an offensive coordinator continue to call up plays where every receiver travels a 6 yard route on a 3rd and 10, you are nuts. Good people =/= good fits for this position.

Mr. Shoop is a fine man, but Purdue's offense was simply horrible. I love the New York Times, but I feel that this article slanders an Athletic Director who is known as a good man and a straight shooter. Shoop's offensive style didn't fit the personnel. Purdue fans universally called for his firing last year and this year his stats worsened. Attacking the integrity of Morgan Burke when Shoop clearly wasn't performing his job adequately, is a cheap shot.

Its also a different NRA.  Up until 1976, before the 'takeover' of their board, they were interested in working with congress on common sense gun safety and control.  After the takeover, the paranoiacs were in control, to the point that they funded a decades-long effort to redefine the traditional meaning and interpretation of the 2nd Amendment from 'militia' to 'personal right'.  Once we've had enough of that linguistic nonsense, things will gradually settle down to 'normal'.  But I don't expect it in my lifetime anymore.
Garbage.  Worst offense in Big10.  He was fired by practically destroying 3 Elite 11 quarterbacks in two years.   Incompetent.   The Old Gray Lady should be ashamed of this piece of trash journalism.
The University of Oregon would not hire John Shoop for water boy.  You are easily 'conned'.

What a load of BS. Anyone who has watched Purdue football over the past 3 years knows that Shoop and his complex offense was a steaming pile of you know what. He's failed far more than he has succeeded as a coach. He may be a fine human being, good for him. But like other comments have said, to connect a firing with his beliefs is ridiculous. Did Hazell safe his skin by firing the coordinators? Perhaps. But they all need to go, every single person on that staff.

You obviously did not watch a single Purdue game over the past 3 years.  Shoop was a horrible OC.  He was fired in spite of his views on player rights, not because of them.  IMHO, he was given one year too long, and should have been fired after last season's offensive mess. What about the fans rights after being subjected to the massive amount of pain he put us Purdue fans through having to watch this mess on the field week-after-week?
Yes it's an important story

Wow. Not sure what else to say. Wow. This wreaks of personal bias. This is a man who has been fired from every OC related job he has ever held. Other comments are focusing on Purdue being at the bottom of the Big Ten offensive stats. Please. Try national stats. We had to put up monster numbers against a horrible Indiana defense in our last game just to crack the top 100 this year in total yards. His player development was poor, his inability to adjust was glaring, and his playcalling was uncreative. He might be a good man, but he's a horrible football coach.

PS - Don't feel the need in the future to venture into a football conversation because you googled some stat definitions and wrote down a handful of scores that someone found for you. The 38 point game was against an FCS opponent (at least we won - that's not a given anymore) and the 36 point game was against Indiana, who by the way allowed teams to score an average of 37 points on them, the lowest score allowed being the FCS game where they held their opponent to 22. Not exactly gold-star worthy. Go find a story somewhere, because this isn't one.

Yes, Coach Shoop is a terrible developer of college quarterbacks, among many other specific job-related deficiencies, and deserved to be fired last year.

Yes, Mr. Nocera has a book in the works about student-athletes' rights, so this is partly a hype article for it. And it's partly a defense of his friend who failed at his job.

That said, many, many college athletics fans agree with more flexibility and support for the players who toil to make all the money that the NCAA, BTN, etc. enjoy.
Jeffdavis, is the firing of every bad football coach a story worthy of coverage by the NYT?1

Regardless of the Shoop's views Joe, he was fired because the offense was the worst in the Big10 for 3 years. Period.  It is great that yo are backing up your friend, John Shoop nearly destroyed the careers of three Elite 11 quarterbacks.  Do you have the ability to comprehend that fact?  You, sir, are pushing your agenda.

Oh give me a break! Purdue's football team frankly sucks...why wouldn't a coach/some coaches be let go...Shoop was not the only coach let go. As for those oh-so-poor athletes...well, let me tell you a little story. I'm from Los Angeles & it's no great secret here that the reason there has been no NFL team back in Los Angeles in close to 20 years is because there is/has been for a long time a professional football team here...it's called USC.
As a female, white, non-athlete who was never offered a scholarship to USC despite a 4.0 average & 1 1480 SAT score,it still rankles me..never-mind how many years later...how many football players who could barely read were admitted to USC played out their football eligibility & then dropped out.
